importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 boys' world youth championship in Antalya, Turkey, gaining international attention at age 12.
Naroditsky earned the title of chess grandmaster by winning the 2013 US Junior Championship at age 17.
Naroditsky was hired by The New York Times as a chess columnist and contributed to a series of chess puzzles for its games section.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: From 2007 to 2025, Naroditsky remained a central figure in chess content creation, influencing players globally through YouTube and livestreams.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, a US chess grandmaster and popular YouTube chess commentator, died at age 29.
He was a key figure in popularising chess content online, with nearly 500,000 YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers.
Naroditsky inspired hundreds of thousands of people to play chess, especially beginners, through engaging tutorials and livestreams.
He was praised by peers such as Hikaru Nakamura and Nemo Zhou for his calm demeanor, passion, and deep knowledge of chess history.
Naroditsky won the under-12 world youth championship in 2007 and earned grandmaster status in 2013.
He published a book titled 'Mastering Positional Chess' at age 14 and later worked as a chess coach in Charlotte, North Carolina.
He was hired by The New York Times in 2022 as a chess columnist and contributed to its games section.
His late-night streams and speed runs made him a standout in the online chess content space.
He had a genuine passion for chess, not financial gain, and was known for his kindness and deep historical knowledge of the game.
Amateur players across the world, including Zara Graham from the UK, credited him as a pivotal inspiration to start playing chess.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a US chess grandmaster and popular YouTube chess commentator, died at the age of 29. He gained international attention in 2007 after winning the under-12 world youth championship in Turkey and earned the grandmaster title in 2013. Known for his engaging video tutorials, livestreams, and bullet chess content, Naroditsky amassed nearly 500,000 YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers. He was widely praised by peers like Hikaru Nakamura and Nemo Zhou for his calm demeanor, passion, and deep knowledge of chess history. His content inspired hundreds of thousands of players, including amateur chess enthusiasts like Zara Graham from the UK, to begin or continue playing the game. Naroditsky's work helped popularise chess content online, with the International Chess Federation acknowledging his pivotal role. He was a respected columnist for The New York Times and a former student of Stanford University. His death has been mourned by fans and fellow players worldwide, highlighting his profound impact on both the game and its digital community.
title: Daniel Naroditsky, US chess grandmaster, dies aged 29
